what: Easily Install and Load the Sigverse
title: Easily Install and Load the Sigverse
text: sigverse simplifies evaluation, exploration, visualisation mutational signatures R.  turnkey mutational signature analysis, see sigscreen. sigverse seek provide custom implementations running signature analyses. simply provides tools evaluating, exploring, reporting results signature analyses done existing signature analysis frameworks (recommend sigminer ’re using R). WARNING: Sigverse early development, yet ready use

title: Easily Install and Load the Sigverse
text: can install development version sigverse GitHub :

title: Easily Install and Load the Sigverse
text: Visualise Signatures  Visualise Catalogues Note access TCGA catalogues first install datasets using remotes::install_github("selkamand/TCGAcatalogues")  Visualise Signature Model primary output signature analyse model describes set signatures , combined certain weights approximate observed mutational pattern sample. example model might look like Signature1 * 0.2 + Signature2 * 0.3 + Signature3 * 0.5 = Simulated Catalogue (hopefully) represents observed profile. can visualise signature model follows  Visualize cohort Warning Cohort visualisations yet available sigverse ’ve got sequencing results cohort, sigvis lets either. Visualise results sample interest context broader cohort Visualise cohort trends input visualiser ‘cohort signature dataframe’ (see sigvis details)
code: library(sigverse) #> ── Attaching core sigverse packages ───────────────────── sigverse 0.0.0.9000 ── #> ✔ sigshared 0.0.0.9000     ✔ sigstats  0.0.0.9000 #> ✔ sigsim    0.0.0.9000     ✔ sigstory  1.0        #> ✔ sigstash  0.0.0.9000     ✔ sigvis    0.0.0.9000  # Load signatures from sigstash signatures <- sig_load("COSMIC_v3.3.1_SBS_GRCh38")  # Visualise a single signature sig_visualise(signatures[["SBS5"]]) #> ✔ All channels matched perfectly to set [sbs_96]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ All types matched perfectly to set [sbs_type]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ Types matched perfectly to palette [snv_type] # Load mutational profile catalogue from the TCGAcatalogues package library(TCGAcatalogues)  brca_catalalogue <- catalogues_load('BRCA')  # Visualise an observed mutational catalogue sig_visualise(   brca_catalalogue[['TCGA-BH-A18P-01A-11D-A12B-09']],   class = "catalogue"   ) #> ✔ All channels matched perfectly to set [sbs_96]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ All types matched perfectly to set [sbs_type]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ Types matched perfectly to palette [snv_type] # Load a signature from sigstash signatures <- sig_load("COSMIC_v3.3.1_SBS_GRCh38")  # Build a signature model signature 'SBS2' explains 40% of the mutations in a sample, and 'SBS13' explains the remaining 60% model = sig_combine(signatures, model = c('SBS2' = 0.4, 'SBS13' = 0.6), format = "combined")  # Visualise the model sig_visualise(model, class = 'model') #> ✔ All channels matched perfectly to set [sbs_96]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ All types matched perfectly to set [sbs_type]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ Types matched perfectly to palette [snv_type] # Load cohort signature results from sigstash cohort = sig_load_sigstash_tcga('BRCA')  # Visualise Cohort sig_visualise_cohort(cohort)   # Contextualize Sample with Cohort Results sig_visualise_sample_in_cohort(cohort, 'TCGA-D8-A1XU')

title: Easily Install and Load the Sigverse
text: Warning Interactive sample reports yet available sigverse running signature analysis sample interest, produce html report describing result. core report generation engine requires high level information signature analyses output, irrespective exact methods used. example manually define properties model demonstrate expected inputs
code: # Specify your catalogue observed_catalogue = example_catalogue  # Specify your model model = c('SBS1' = 0.4, 'SBS2' = 0.5)  # Specify aetiologies of any signatures in your model aetiology = list(   SBS1 = 'Spontaneous deamination of 5-methylcytosine (clock like signature)',   SBS2 = 'Activity of APOBEC family of cytidine deaminases'   )  # Specify similar samples (optional, only supply if you want to compare to some larger cohort) similar_samples = data.frame(   sample_id = c('Sample1', 'Sample2', 'Sample3'),   cosine_similarity = c(0.96, 0.95, 0.8) )   # Produce the html report sig_story(   observed = observed_catalogue   model = model,   aetiology = aetiology,   similar_samples = similar_samples )

title: Easily Install and Load the Sigverse
text: Warning Simulation functions yet available sigverse sigsim allows simulate mutational catalogues combining different mutational signatures, plus spike known amounts noise. can useful benchmarking signature tools.
code: # Load signatures from sigstash signatures <- sig_load("COSMIC_v3.3.1_SBS_GRCh38")   # Simulate Signatures sig_simulate(signatures, c('SBS3' = 0.5, "SBS4" = 0.5))

title: Easily Install and Load the Sigverse
text: sigstats contains functionality compute basic signature related statistics. example, computing cosine similarity two mutational catalogues.

title: Easily Install and Load the Sigverse
text: sigshared collection utilities packages sigverse use. contains functions help identify input types, assert ’re expected.

title: Easily Install and Load the Sigverse
text: sigverse needs work downstream many different signature analysis tools. maximise interoperability expected inputs simple dataframes lists, rather sigverse specific S3/S4/R8/R7 objects. data types used sigverse packages described sigshared documentation

title: Easily Install and Load the Sigverse
text: signature analysis packages provide suite visualisation exploration tools. simplify software stack, recommend using sigverse following reasons: run multiple signature analysis tools want uniform way exploring results want benchmark signature analysis packages Find missing functionality (e.g. cohort signature result exploration / reporting modules)

title: Easily Install and Load the Sigverse
text: sigstash signature collections sigvis signature visualisation sigstats signature statistics (e.g. cosine similarity) sigsim simulating signatures / sample profiles sigstory reporting results signature analyses sigshared utilities used many sigverse packages

title: Easily Install and Load the Sigverse
text: TCGAcatalogues loading TCGA sample catalogues
